Award.AwardTitle: CIF:Small: Collaborative Research:Theoretical Foundation of Distributed Wireless Channel Access

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Due to lack of fundamental understanding on how to share wireless media among spatially distributed users, the energy consumption and bandwidth efficiency of wireless networks remains defficient and highly suboptimal. Prior investigations of wireless channel access have followed two separate paths that reflect vastly different viewpoints; namely, the traditional information-theoretic approach assumes perfect user coordination and ignores the modularized network architecture, while the traditional network-theoretic approach largely focuses on access control protocols and ignores the impact of the physical layer. This project will bridge the gap of the classical theories by developing a theoretical foundation for channel access in distributed wireless systems. More specifically, it will extend classical information theory by developing a channel coding theory for physical layer distributed communication, where users do not jointly design channel codes. It will also extend classical network theory by developing a medium access control (MAC) framework for distributed networking, where physical layer properties, such as joint multiuser message decoding and flexible adaptation of communication parameters, are efficiently exploited at the link layer.

The project contains two parts which respectively address the physical and the data link layers of distributed wireless networks. In Part I of the project, the goal is to develop a rigorous coding theory to characterize the fundamental limitis of distributed communication systems. The coding theory will support extensive communication performance tradeoffs and structured coding schemes with low computational complexity. Part II of the project contains three steps. The objective of the first step is to characterize optimal link layer distributed channel sharing schemes, their fundamental properties and performance improvements over classical schemes. The objective of the second step is to develop a unified MAC framework to achieve asymptotic optimal channel sharing in distributed networks via the joint adaptation of communication parameters (e.g., rate, power, transmission probability). The objective of the third step is to develop MAC algorithms with fast convergence properties that ensure efficient network operation in transient environments.

By extending information theory to distributed communication models, the project will advance the integration of information and network theories, and significantly improve the energy and bandwidth efficiency of wireless systems. Unification of the two classical theories will also influence the way modern communication network subjects are taught in Higher Education and attract more talented students to this field of acute national importance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Due to lack of fundamental understanding on how to share wireless media among spatially distributed users, the energy and bandwidth efficiency of wireless networks remains highly lagging and suboptimal. Prior investigations of wireless channel access have followed two separate paths that reflect vastly different viewpoints; namely, the traditional information-theoretic approach assumes perfect user coordination and ignores the modularized network architecture, while the traditional network-theoretic approach largely focuses on access control protocols and ignores the impact of physical layer. Consequently, for distributed systems when users only have limited opportunity to exchange information, the fundamental issue of efficient channel sharing remains unresolved.

This project is developed based on a research vision that architectural inefficiency in wireless part of the network can be solved by a physical-link layer interface enhancement. The enhanced interface equips each link layer user with multiple transmission options, which enables advanced wireless communication adaptation at the data link layer. To support the enhanced physical-link layer interface, at the physical layer, we extended the classical Shannon-type channel coding theory to distributed communication system. We defined and derived the distributed channel capacity of a multiple access channel, and showed that it coincides with the classical Shannon capacity. We further obtained achievable performance bound when users have a finite codeword length. At the data link layer, we developed a distributed medium access control algorithm that can help users to exploit the multiple transmission options and to adapt their transmission schemes to a near optimal option with respect to an arbitrarily chosen utility.

Our work represents the first channel coding theory to support the distributed communication model, and the first medium access control algorithm to support multiple transmission options at each link layer user. Our results are important additions to the long term effort of integrating information theory with network theory. Fundamental understandings about distributed communication and networking has the potential of significantly improving the energy and bandwidth efficiency of wireless systems. The joint consideration of efficiency in wireless communication and modularity in computer network architecture will help to put different aspects of communication networks into perspective, and will influence the way modern communication network subjects are taught in Higher Education and attract more talented students to this field of acute national importance.
